lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, properties, or props for short, are a way to pass data to a component.

They allow components to be dynamic and customizable.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far, we've created components without passing any arguments, meaning they always display the same static content.

However, to make components more dynamic, we can pass props as arguments to the components to customize what they show.

Make sure to pick props.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
We pass one argument, props, representing an object that holds all the data passed to the component in one place.

In the component, we access props as we access any passed parameters.

Make sure to pick props, followed by props.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
As props is an object, we can access the properties of that object.

To access the name, we use props.name.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally name.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use props inside JSX.

Display the name by accessing the name property of the props object inside the curly braces by coding props.name.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally name.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using JavaScript inside JSX, we need to put the JavaScript inside curly braces.

Add the curly braces to ensure the JavaScript will be rendered correctly.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To pass a property to a component, add it as an attribute in the componentâ€™s tag, similar to setting attributes in HTML.

First, define the attribute's name, then assign it a value inside quotes.

Make sure to pick name, followed by =, and finally "Eve".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use props to display a custom message.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally text.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be printed by this React app?

<h1>Greetings, Agent Smith</h1><h1>Greetings, Neo</h1>

<h1>Greetings, Agent Smith</h1>.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure that the component accepts props as its argument.

Make sure to type props.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the method to access the value of a property passed as a prop in a React component?

props.propertyNamethis.props.propertyName

Make sure to pick props.propertyName.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use an embedded expression to render the passed name in an unordered list.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., name, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we pass the prop planet="Tatooine" to a component, how will you display it using JSX?

<p>{props.planet}</p><p>props.planet</p>

Make sure to pick <p>{props.planet}</p>.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've already learned how to pass a property to a component.

Make sure to pick name, followed by =, and finally "Adam".

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
We're not limited to only passing one property. If we want to pass multiple properties, we can do so.

Pass the string "Eden" as the value for the property location.

Make sure to pick location, followed by =, and finally "Eden".

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can access every passed property as we've done before.

Access the property location from the props object.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., location, }.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we pass multiple properties, they become part of the props object, allowing us to access each one through it.

Log the props object to see what properties have been passed and their values.

Make sure to pick console followed by . and then log, props.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to access multiple passed properties.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., favoriteColor, props.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will this code display?

My favorite color is Bruce WayneMy favorite color is blueMy favorite food is pizza

My favorite color is Bruce Wayne.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass multiple properties in a component to display a movie character's info.

James Bond is a character in SkyfallEthan Hunt is a character in Mission Impossible

Make sure to pick name followed by "James Bond" and then movie, "Skyfall".

James Bond is a character in Skyfall.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use another prop to pass a favorite snack to the component.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally main.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass multiple properties in a component to display a movie character's info.

Make sure to pick "Ethan Hunt", followed by "Mission Impossible".

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass properties to render personal details in the Details component.

Make sure to pick name followed by hobby and then name, hobby.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can pass other types as properties as well, such as numbers.

When passing non-strings, like numbers, we need to wrap the value in curly braces {}.

Make sure to pick {, followed by 69, and finally }.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When accessing a passed property, the type doesnâ€™t matter; whether itâ€™s a number or a string, we access them all by their key.

Access the property age from the passed props object.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., age, }.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
Passing booleans works similarly.

Pass the value true for the key nice.

Make sure to pick {, followed by true, and finally }.

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
However, in React, we can't render a boolean directly as a string. We won't see anything if we try to render a boolean value directly.

Try to render the passed property nice, which holds a boolean value.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., nice, }.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to render a boolean (or a number) as a string, we can use the String(value) to convert a given variable called value to a string.

Use the String function and pass props.nice as the argument to get a string back that we can display.

Make sure to pick String, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the passed number in the Score component.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., value, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
If you want to pass a score of 42 as a prop to a component, which is the correct syntax?

score="42"score={42}score=42

Make sure to pick score={42}.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass a number to the Player component.

Make sure to pick level= followed by { and then 5, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you display the level of the player using the passed property?

props.levelprops.level()

Make sure to pick props.level.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render the passed boolean isActive property.

Make sure to pick String followed by ( and then props, ., isActive, ).

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you pass a boolean value of false to a prop?

isOnline={false}isOnline="false"

Make sure to pick isOnline={false}.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Convert a boolean property to a string for display.

Make sure to pick String, followed by (, and finally ).
